event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: If the problem can be isolated to a specific XSB, schedule a repair action to replace the affected Field Replaceable Unit (FRU), the identity of which can be determined using fmdump -v -u EVENT_ID. Please consult the detail section of the knowledge article for additional information.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: XSCF software detected a problem on the command interface between the XSCF and an XSB.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
XSCF software detected a problem on the command interface between the XSCF and an XSB.


   SPARC Enterprise M3000:

      Faults that can be isolated to a specific MBC chip will result in no immediate action taken.
      The platform becomes unbootable.

      Faults that cannot be isolated to a specific MBC chip will result in nothing to be deconfigured,
      as there will  not be a FRU identified with the fault.


   SPARC Enterprise M4000:

      Faults that can be isolated to a  specific MBC chip, the XSCF switches the command
      interface to another XSB in the domain with a functioning command interface.
      If there is no alternate XSB to use, then no immediate action is taken for this case.

      Faults that cannot be isolated to a specific MBC chip, the XSCF is rebooted.

      If the fault can be isolated to a specific XSB on a specific MBC chip (this can be determined
      by examining the FMRI of the fault), the system will switch to use some other XSB's command interface,
      if there is an operational command interface on another XSB in this domain.
      Otherwise, the domain will continue to use the existing command interface.
   
      If the fault is isolated to a specific MBC chip, but not to a specific XSB,
      then  the platform will gradually  become unbootable as domains will not be allowed to reboot.



   SPARC Enterprise M5000:

      Faults that can be isolated to a  specific MBC chip, the XSCF switches the command
      interface to another XSB in the domain with a functioning command interface.
      If there is no alternate XSB to use, then no immediate action is taken for this case.

      Faults that cannot be isolated to a specific MBC chip, the XSCF is rebooted.

      If the fault can be isolated to a specific XSB on a specific MBC chip (this can be determined
      by examining the FMRI of the fault), the system will switch to use some other XSB's command interface,
      if there is an operational command interface on another XSB in this domain.
      Otherwise, the domain will continue to use the existing command interface.

      If the fault is isolated to a specific MBC chip, but not to a specific XSB,
      then half the Motherboard with the MBC chip is deconfigured after the domains using the
      half the Motherboard reboot or after the domains stop using the half the Motherboard
      due to a DR operation.



   SPARC Enterprise M8000/M9000:

      Faults that can be isolated to a  specific MBC chip, the XSCF switches the command
      interface to another XSB in the domain with a functioning command interface.
      If there is no alternate XSB to use, then no immediate action is taken for this case.

      Faults that cannot be isolated to a specific MBC chip, the standby XSCF will take over as the active XSCF.

      If the fault can be isolated to a specific XSB on a specific MBC chip (this can be determined
      by examining the FMRI of the fault), the system will switch to use some other XSB's command interface,
      if there is an operational command interface on another XSB in this domain.
      Otherwise, the domain will continue to use the existing command interface.

      If the fault is isolated to a specific MBC chip, but not to a specific XSB,
      then all XSBs on  the CMU are deconfigured when the domains using the CMU
      reboot or the domains stop using the XSB due to a DR operation.



The recommended service action for this event is to schedule the replacement of the affected FRU.

       LEGEND

      RED        = SUNW-MSG-ID
      BLUE     = EVENT_ID
      GREEN  = FRU


Step 1. Collect the fault message (use one of the following methods):


   Single-line fault message displayed on the XSCF console:

   Mar 20 21:22:56 san-ff2-21-0 fmd: SOURCE: sde, REV: 1.12, CSN: 7860000772  
   EVENT-ID: 776228e4-30bb-447e-931e-2dea5a46de5c
   Refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/ SCF-8003-PD for detailed information.


   Complete fault message using 'fmdump -m' on the XSCF console:

   MSG-ID:  SCF-8003-PD, TYPE: Fault, VER: 1, SEVERITY: Major
   EVENT-TIME: Tue Mar 20 21:22:56 UTC 2007
   PLATFORM: SPARC-Enterprise, CSN: 7860000772, HOSTNAME: san-ff2-21-0
   SOURCE: sde, REV: 1.12
   EVENT-ID: 776228e4-30bb-447e-931e-2dea5a46de5c
   DESC: XSCF software detected a problem on the command interface between the XSCF and an XSB.
   Refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SCF-8003-PD for more information.
   AUTO-RESPONSE: If the problem can be isolated to a specific XSB, the system will switch to use some other XSB's
   command interface, if there is an operational command interface on another XSB in this domain. Otherwise,
   the system will continue to use the existing command interface. The XSB with this command interface will
   be deconfigured after the platform is power cycled or after the domain reboots or after a Dynamic
   Reconfiguration operation is performed. If the problem cannot be isolated to a specific XSB, no
   deconfiguration is performed. Please consult the detail section of the knowledge article for additional
   information.
   IMPACT: No immediate impact.
   REC-ACTION: If the problem can be isolated to a specific XSB, schedule a repair action to replace the affected
   Field Replaceable Unit (FRU), the identity of which can be determined using fmdump -v -u EVENT_ID.
   Please consult the detail section of the knowledge article for additional information.


Step 2. Collect the output from the 'fmdump -v -u EVENT_ID' command

   
   SPARC Enterprise platform example:
 
   xscf> fmdump -v -u 776228e4-30bb-447e-931e-2dea5a46de5c

         TIME                 UUID                                 MSG-ID
         Mar 20 21:22:56.7479 776228e4-30bb-447e-931e-2dea5a46de5c SCF-8003-PD
           100%  fault.chassis.SPARC-Enterprise.asic.mbc.se-cmd

                 Problem in: hc:///chassis=0/cmu=0/xsb=0
                    Affects: hc:///chassis=0/cmu=0/xsb=0
                        FRU: hc://:product-id=SPARC-Enterprise:chassis-id=7860000772:
                             server-id=san-ff2-21-0:
                             part=CA20393-B50X 001AA:revision=0101/component=/MBU_B


Step 3. Contact your Authorized Service Provider.



If you require additional information, please refer to InfoDoc #87402.
event_registry_properties.name: impact
response
event_registry_properties.item: If the problem can be isolated to a specific XSB, the system will switch to use some other XSB's command interface, if there is an operational command interface on another XSB in this domain. Otherwise, the system will continue to use the existing command interface. The XSB with this command interface will be deconfigured after the platform is power cycled or after the domain reboots or after a Dynamic Reconfiguration operation is performed. If the problem cannot be isolated to a specific XSB, no deconfiguration is performed. Please consult the detail section of the knowledge article for additional information.
event_registry_properties.name: title
event_registry_properties.item: XSCF software detected a problem between the XSCF and an XSB.
